title: Apple TV+ Is Being Sold at a Big Discount. Earnings Could Suffer, Goldman Sachs Warns.
text:
Text size

Apple TV+ will come free for a year with the purchase of a new iPhone, iPad, Apple TV, iPod Touch, or Mac.

While that deal could lead to paid subscriptions in the future, how Apple (ticker: AAPL) accounts for this discount could hurt several key measures in the company’s earnings report, according to an analyst at Goldman Sachs.

The back story. Apple sent shockwaves through the streaming world when it said its Apple TV+ offering will only cost $4.99 and come free for a year when you buy one of several new devices.

Though the actual impact on rivals such as Netflix (NFLX) and Walt Disney (DIS) may be overstated due to the huge disparity between available content on competing platforms, services like Apple TV+ have become increasingly key to the company’s growth and future earnings stability.

What's new. Goldman analyst Rod Hall suggested in a note to clients Friday that a free year of Apple TV+ will hurt average selling prices on the products it comes with, as well as gross profits and earnings per share. That’s if the company follows a similar accounting approach as it does with Apple Maps and Siri.

Editor's Choice

If someone bought a new iPhone 11 Pro for $1,000 (rounding up to simplify math) and signed up for the TV+ trial, they are actually buying an iPhone 11 Pro and TV+ bundle, valued at around $1,060, Hall noted.

Instead of the discount being applied to only TV+ revenue, he suggests it would be applied to the whole package. That means the average selling price for the iPhone Pro would fall to $943.40, while the TV+ revenue would be discounted to $56.60.

“Effectively, Apple’s method of accounting moves revenue from hardware to Services even though customers do not perceive themselves to be paying for TV+,” he wrote. “Though this might appear convenient for Apple’s services revenue line it is equally inconvenient” for hardware average selling prices, gross profits, and earnings per share in “high sales quarters” such as the first quarter of fiscal 2020, which ends in December.

An Apple representative did not immediately return a request for comment.

Apple stock was down 2.35% to $217.84 in Friday afternoon trading, while the broader S&P 500 index was about flat.

Looking Ahead. Hall has a Neutral rating on Apple stock. His $165 price target implies 26% downside from the closing price on Thursday.

He estimates this accounting practice will cause average selling prices for iPhones to fall to $943.40 in the fiscal first quarter, at a lower gross margin since the cost of goods sold is unaffected by discounting.

“The discounted TV+ revenue shows up as a credit to Deferred Revenue and then will be recognized on a monthly basis over the 12-month trial period,” he noted. “We believe that TV+ COGS will be allocated to this revenue stream on a monthly basis as well.”

His estimate, assuming a 25% gross margin contribution for the trial revenue, results in a negative impact to earnings per share of 16% in the first quarter and 14% for fiscal 2020, though it will have no impact on cash flow.

He also assumes the offer will only run for one year. “Should it run longer, our out-year forecasts would also likely need to be adjusted in a similar way.”

Write to Connor Smith at connor.smith@barrons.com
description: Apple TV+ will come free for a year with the purchase of a new iPhone and other products. Goldman says accounting for the deal could cause average selling prices for iPhones to fall to $943.40 in the fiscal first quarter, at a lower gross margin.
